verses.text: After the Sabbath, at dawn on the first day of the week, Mary Magdalene and the other Mary went to look at the tomb.
verses.comment: The timing emphasizes fulfillment of Jesus' prophecy about rising on the third day (cf. Matt. 16:21); the prominent role of Mary Magdalene is notable throughout resurrection accounts.

verses.text: And suddenly, there was a great earthquake, for an angel of the Lord descended from heaven and came and rolled back the stone and sat on it.
verses.comment: The earthquake and angelic appearance mark this as a divine intervention, reinforcing that Christ's resurrection is an act of God (compare Acts 2:24).

verses.text: His appearance was like lightning, and his clothing was white as snow.
verses.comment: Angels appearing in glory signify heavenly authority (cf. Daniel 10:6), connecting with Old Testament visions.

verses.text: And for fear of him, the guards trembled and became like dead men.
verses.comment: The guards' paralysis highlights God's power and contrasts with the boldness inspired in believers by resurrection faith.

verses.text: But the angel said to the women, 'Do not be afraid, for I know that you are looking for Jesus who was crucified.'
verses.comment: The angel's message echoes 'Do not be afraid' announcements in other divine encounters, affirming God's intention to comfort his people.

verses.text: 'He is not here; for he has risen, just as he said. Come, see the place where he lay.'
verses.comment: Fulfills Jesus' own prophecy of resurrection; a pivotal verse for Christology, confirming Jesus’ divinity by demonstrating his power over death.

verses.text: 'Then go quickly and tell his disciples that he has risen from the dead, and see, he is going before you into Galilee; there you will see him. Listen, I have told you.'
verses.comment: By sending the witnesses to the disciples, the angel is directing the formation of the early community around the risen Lord—a foundation moment for the church’s apostolic mission.

verses.text: So they hurried away from the tomb, fearful yet extremely joyful, and ran to bring his disciples the news.
verses.comment: The mixture of fear and joy becomes characteristic of resurrection encounters, signaling both awe of the divine and the hope received through faith.

verses.text: And suddenly, Jesus met them and said, 'Greetings!' And they came to him, took hold of his feet, and worshiped him.
verses.comment: The women worship Jesus, indicating his divine status. In first-century Jewish context, worship is due to God alone (cf. Exodus 20:5). This is a major pointer to Jesus' divinity.

verses.text: Then Jesus said to them, 'Do not be afraid. Go and tell my brothers to go to Galilee. There they will see me.'
verses.comment: 'My brothers' deepens the relationship between Jesus and his disciples, pointing to a new family formed in faith. Galilee as the meeting place fulfills prophecy and symbolizes mission to the nations.

verses.text: While they were going, some of the guards went into the city and reported to the chief priests everything that had happened.
verses.comment: The guards go to the religious authorities rather than civil ones; this reinforces the role of the high priestly class in opposing Jesus’ mission.

verses.text: And when they assembled with the elders and formed a plan, they gave a large sum of money to the soldiers,
verses.comment: Bribery plays a part in suppressing truth about Jesus. Compare Judas' betrayal earlier for silver, highlighting the corrupting power of money.

verses.text: saying, 'Tell people, “His disciples came by night and stole him away while we were sleeping.”'
verses.comment: The lie echoes past attempts to undermine divine works by attributing them to human deceit, yet the power of eyewitness testimony prevails.

verses.text: 'If this reaches the governor’s ears, we will persuade him and keep you out of trouble.'
verses.comment: Reveals the high priestly authorities’ determination to maintain power; earthly authority contrasts heavenly truth which cannot be suppressed.

verses.text: So they took the money and did as they were instructed; and this story has been spread among the Jews to this day.
verses.comment: Matthew notes the persistence of the alternative narrative, underscoring the need for faithful witness to the resurrection.

verses.text: Now the eleven disciples went to Galilee, to the mountain where Jesus had directed them.
verses.comment: The mountain setting recalls covenant events in biblical history (cf. Sinai), suggesting continuity with Old Testament revelation and emphasizing authoritative teaching.

verses.text: And when they saw him, they worshiped him, though some doubted.
verses.comment: Worship given to Jesus again signals recognition of his divinity. The mention of doubt affirms the reality of their experience and gradual growth in faith.

verses.text: And Jesus came and said to them, 'All authority in heaven and on earth has been given to me.'
verses.comment: This explicit claim to universal authority fulfills Old Testament messianic prophecy and confirms Jesus' divine kingship. The transmission of authority is foundational for the church’s leadership and sacramental mission.

verses.text: 'Go therefore and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit,'
verses.comment: This trinitarian formula is evidence for early belief in the triune nature of God. Baptism here is instituted by Christ himself, transmitted through apostolic authority. The command underscores both the importance of sacramental initiation and worldwide mission.

verses.text: 'teaching them to observe all that I have commanded you. And surely, I am with you always, even to the end of the age.'
verses.comment: Christ pledges his abiding presence, echoing God’s covenant promise never to forsake his people. Apostolic teaching becomes the living tradition of the faith passed through generations, fulfilling the promise of divine guidance and unity until the consummation.
